title: First-Principles Market Deconstruction — Paste-ready prompt
instruction: Deconstruct the market for [Core Job-to-be-Done] from first principles. Produce: (A) a one‑page ecosystem map listing Key Players (names/types), Value Flows (who pays whom and why), and Economic Incentives for each actor; (B) the five highest‑friction nodes ranked by impact and why; (C) three sources of value leakage (how money or attention is lost today); (D) a recommended one‑sentence manifesto: our vision for a new solution and three tactical moves to get initial traction.
output: Ecosystem table + numbered list + 1‑sentence entry point
success_criteria: Clear actors, measurable friction points and realistic next steps
follow_up: Turn friction node #1 into a 90‑day experiment plan

title: Non‑Consumption Segmentation — Who's left out?
instruction: Identify who cannot consume existing solutions for [Job-to-be-Done]. Split the non‑consumers into segments by Skill (lack of ability), Access (geography/price/tech) and Time (speed). For each segment provide: a size estimate, aspiration (low/medium/high), behavioural profile, the top three barriers and an MVP idea that removes exactly one barrier.
output: Three‑row table (Skill/Access/Time) × columns: Size, Profile, Barriers, MVP
success_criteria: Practical MVP ideas targeted to unlock large segments
follow_up: Prioritise the three MVPs using ICE (Impact, Confidence, Ease — give scores)

title: Value Chain Snapshot — Current vs digital‑first
instruction: Map the current value chain delivering [Outcome] to [User Persona]. For each stage list: actor, cost driver, margin capture and inefficiency (time/cost/error). Then propose a digital‑first, six‑step simplified value chain and highlight which incumbents lose pricing power.
output: Two tables: Current value chain; Proposed digital chain with delta notes
success_criteria: Clear delta showing where value is captured today and how to shift it
follow_up: Estimate the percentage margin reallocation if step 3 is automated

title: Adjacent Market Threat Scan — three markets
instruction: For [Market A], [Market B] and [Market C] identify dominant players, their key assets (data, distribution, tech) and evaluate (Low/Medium/High) the feasibility that they enter our space [Our Core Problem]. For each scenario analyse wedge and timing as well as time‑to‑entry (6/12/24 months).
output: Three mini‑profiles with feasibility, wedge and timeline
success_criteria: Actionable list of likely entrants and early‑warning signals to monitor
follow_up: Recommend three defensive moves to blunt Market B’s wedge

title: Regulatory Moat brainstorming (industry‑specific)
instruction: List nuanced regulatory, compliance or standards‑based barriers in [Industry] beyond GDPR/HIPAA that could become moats. For each: name the rule or standard, explain the operational complexity (data residency, cross‑jurisdiction, certification cost) and propose a product feature or process that turns compliance into a customer acquisition advantage.
output: Table with columns: Regulation, Complexity, Opportunity, Acquisition leverage
success_criteria: At least four defendable compliance moats with quick wins
follow_up: Estimate initial cost and 12‑month timeline to implement your top pick

title: Economic Model Stress Test — three scenarios
instruction: Model unit economics for solving [Problem] under High‑volume low‑touch, Low‑volume high‑touch and Hybrid scenarios. For each scenario compute: Revenue per unit, Cost‑to‑serve (infrastructure, support), Contribution margin, Payback period, Customer acquisition cost (CAC) and breakeven usage rate. Use realistic variable drivers such as ARPU = [x], infrastructure per user = [y] and support per ticket = [z].
output: Three scenario tables plus the top three sensitivity drivers per scenario
follow_up: Draft a memo summarising which scenario to pursue

title: Buyer economics: where value accrues today
instruction: Produce a waterfall showing how a $100 buyer spend for [Outcome] gets distributed across ecosystem players today (percentages to vendor, platform, integrator, reseller, tax). Use assumptions or say 'assume' and list them.
success_criteria: Clear visibility of value pockets to target
follow_up: Propose redistribution if we introduce a direct‑to‑user model

title: Friction heatmap — Identify top 7 frictions
instruction: List the top seven friction points users face when achieving [Job-to-be-Done] for [Outcome]. For each friction provide: root cause, observed frequency (High/Medium/Low), business impact (dollars or time) and a one‑sentence mitigation idea.
success_criteria: Prioritised frictions by impact multiplied by frequency
follow_up: Turn friction #1 into a measurable KPI and a six‑week experiment

title: Non‑consumption persona one‑pager
instruction: Create a one‑page persona for a non‑consumer segment called [Persona Name] who cannot use existing solutions. Include: demographics, goals, pains, tech access, daily workflow and a 30‑second elevator pitch for how our solution would help them.
success_criteria: Persona usable for recruitment and ideation
follow_up: Write five interview questions to validate this persona’s needs

title: Distribution & channel map
instruction: Map existing distribution channels that deliver [Core Job-to-be-Done] – direct, reseller, marketplaces and partners. For each channel show: channel size, growth rate, margins and one activation tactic to penetrate or leverage.
output: Channel table plus four activation tactics
success_criteria: Clear understanding of channel viability versus resource fit
follow_up: Identify ‘channel‑channel’ strategies to multiply reach (e.g., bundling)
